contentrichtext.text: [[Image:European birch bark.jpg|thumb|right|<Center>The dark horizontal lines on [[Silver birch]] bark are the lenticels.<ref> [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/lenticel "Lenticel"]. ''The American Heritage Science Dictionary'', Houghton Mifflin Company, via dictionary.com. Retrieved on 2007-10-11</ref>]] A '''lenticel''' is a porous tissue consisting of cells with large intercellular spaces in the [[periderm]] of the secondarily thickened organs and the [[bark]] of woody stems and roots of [[dicotyledon]]ous flowering plants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.botgard.ucla.edu/html/botanytextbooks/generalbotany/barkfeatures/fulltextonly.html|author=Arthur C. Gibson|title=General Botany|chapter=Bark features}}</ref> It functions as a pore, providing a pathway for the direct [[gas exchange|exchange of gases]] between the internal tissues and atmosphere through the bark, which are otherwise impermeable to gases. The name lenticel, pronounced with an [{{IPA|s}}], derives from its lenticular ([[lens (optics)|lens]]-like) shape.<ref>{{citation|author=Esau, K.|year=1953|title=Plant Anatomy|publisher=John Wiley & Sons Inc. New York, Chapman & Hall Ltd. London}}</ref> The shape of lenticels is one of the characters used for tree identification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/fr296|title=How to Identify a Tree|author=Michael G. Andreu, Erin M. Givens, and Melissa H. Friedman|publisher=University of Florida IFAS extension}}</ref> ==Formation== Lenticel formation usually begins beneath [[stoma]]tal complexes during primary growth preceding the development of the first [[periderm]]. Lenticels are found as raised circular, oval, or elongated areas on stems and roots. As stems and roots mature lenticel development continues in the new periderm (for example, periderm that forms at the bottom of cracks in the bark). Lenticels are also found in pneumatophorous roots (respiratory roots). {{Clear}} ==Fruits== [[Image:Sterappel.jpg|thumb|right|<Center>Lenticels on apples.]] Lenticels are also present on many fruits, quite noticeably on many apples and pears. On [[European Pear|European pears]], they can serve as an indicator of when to pick the fruit, as light lenticels on immature fruit darken and become brown.<ref>Pyzner, John. (2005-04-19.) [http://www.lsuagcenter.com/news_archive/2004/News+You+Can+Use/Pick+Pears+Before+Completely+Ripe+Advises+LSU+AgCenter+Horticulturist.htm "Pick pears before completely ripe, advises LSU AgCenter horticulturist"]. [[Louisiana State University Agricultural Center]] website. Retrieved on 2007-10-11.</ref> Certain bacterial and fungal infections can penetrate fruits through their lenticels, with susceptibility sometimes increasing with its age.<ref>Irtwange, S. V. (February, 2006.) [http://cigr-ejournal.tamu.edu/submissions/volume8/Invited%20overview%20Irtwange(2)%2027Feb2006.pdf "Application of modified atmosphere packaging and related technology in postharvest handling of fresh fruits and vegetables"]. Agricultural Engineering International: the CIGR Ejournal. Invited Overview No. 4. Vol. VIII, page 8. Retrieved on 2007-10-11.</ref> ==Tubers== Lenticels are also present on potato tubers.<ref>{{cite doi|10.1111/j.1744-7348.1975.tb01582.x}}</ref> ==Further images== <gallery> File:Prunus serrula bark lenticels, Dawyck Botanic Gardens.JPG|Lenticels on Prunus serrula Image:Wild Cherry bark lenticels.JPG|Lenticels on Wild Cherry or Gean. Image:Alder bark and callus.JPG|Alder bark (Alnus glutinosa) with characteristic lenticels and abnormal lenticels on callused areas. </gallery> ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== {{Portal|Trees}} *{{cite book | last =Raven | first =Peter H. | coauthors =Ray F. Evert, Susan E. Eichorn | title =Biology of Plants 7th Ed. | publisher =W.H. Freeman and Company Publishers | year =2005 | pages =586â€“587 | isbn =0-7167-1007-2 }} [[Category:Plant morphology]] [[Category:Trees]] {{Botany-stub}}
